title: Joyce grilled despite profit figure
text:
Email a friend 
QANTAS CEO Alan Joyce has been grilled on the number of part-time workers employed by the carrier, the failed Jetstar Hong Kong venture and the future of Frequent Flyer points earned from shopping at Woolworths. 
Shareholders at the Annual General Meeting in Perth also questioned whether the Flying Kangaroo would have posted a loss if it were not for falling fuel prices and the Australian dollar’s depreciation. 
But Mr Joyce could not be rattled and declared “it was not good luck but good management” that delivered a $557 million after-tax profit in 2014-15. 
He revealed the unsuccessful bid to launch a Jetstar Hong Kong airline cost $30 million, and that Qantas was reviewing its Frequent Flyer partnership with Woolworths, due to expire in December. Strong brand ... Alan Joyce painted a bright future for Qantas at the AGM in Perth. Picture: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg Source: Supplied 
But he denied any failure to renew the deal would have an impact on Qantas profits, which he predicted would grow significantly this financial year. 
Mr Joyce also moved to “set the record straight” on Transport Workers Union claims that the part-time workforce at the airline now outnumbered fulltime employees. 
He said part-timers accounted for 20 per cent of the workforce which was well below the proportion in other industries such as retail and hospitality. 
“We do need to use part-time roles in a lot of areas around the company, and we have some people who have second jobs as well,” Mr Joyce said. 
“I think one of our part-timers is a physio for the Sydney Swans, and we have some people who’ve come back into the workforce for those part-time roles as well.” 
Independent Senator Nick Xenophon posed some of the curliest questions, asking why Qantas still failed to break down financial results for Jetstar Asia, Jetstar Pacific and Jetstar Japan. 
Qantas Chairman Leigh Clifford answered that the results would be revealed in “due course” but conceded the figures were pretty modest. 
“Suffice to say we are quite pleased with the performance certainly in this half, and we’ll obviously give details in due course about the specific performances,” Mr Clifford said. 
Senator Xenophon also questioned whether Qantas would have posted a profit in the last year, had it not been for considerable fuel savings, the Australian dollar’s depreciation and the removal of the carbon tax. King of the skies ... Qantas has plans for further growth internationally in the next year. Picture: AP/Mark Baker Source: AP 
Mr Joyce said the transformation program was “by far the biggest driver” of Qantas’ financial turnaround. 
“You can add up fuel, depreciation and carbon tax and get a big number but not every airline in the world got the benefit of fuel — that was good management,” he said. 
“(In 2014-15) Qantas made more money than Virgin Australia, Air New Zealand and Etihad put together. If everyone was getting the benefit of fuel than that wouldn’t be true.” 
Shareholders voted in favour of Mr Joyce’s $11.8 million salary for the last year, and approved his participation in a long-term incentive program set to deliver more than $2 million in bonuses if key targets are met.
